Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Multi-scale Imaging of Neural Interconnects using MRI-compatible Parallel Photonic Needle Interface

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

#1254743
Chen

The long-term research goal is to establish a new multi-modal imaging platform that combines optical imaging and MRI for multi-scale parallel imaging of neural activity. As a step towards this goal, the proposed research objectives in this CAREER proposal are: 1) Investigate depth-resolved neural physiological changes using multi-contrast OCT; 2) Implement MRI-compatible parallel photonic needle interface (PPNI) for simultaneous MRI/OCT; 3) Establish multi-scale MRI/PPNI-OCT imaging in live
animals. They will apply this novel imaging technique to the mouse trigeminal system, which is associated with patterned array of whisker-related neural modules in various brain structures, and provides an excellent model system to investiate cellular and molecular mechanisms of neural pattern formation and plasticity. They will image populations of whisker-related neurons in the cortex and subcortical trigeminal centers using PPNI-OCT/MRI, which will allow to simultaneously investigate whisker-evoked activity patterns in the brainstem, thalamus, and cortex.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding functional wiring of neural circuits and their patterns of activation following sensory stimulation is a fundamental issue in neurobiology. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is particularly useful for visualizing the location of neural activity, but has limited spatial (~1 mm) and temporal (~1 s) resolutions. In contrast, optical techniques such as optical intrinsic signal imaging (OISI), voltage-sensitive dye (VSD) imaging, and optical coherence tomography (OCT) offer high spatial (~1-10 µm) and temporal (~1-10 ms) resolutions, and can provide unique insights into the coupling between the fast neuronal activation and slow hemodynamic responses. Therefore, a multi-scale imaging system combining and correlating large field-of-view MRI and high-resolution optical imaging can enhance our understanding of the neural basis of brain function, and improve the accuracy of image-guided neurosurgery.

In this study, we have achieved significant progress with 13 peer-reviewed journal publications. Research achievements include: 1) developed multi-scale imaging platform combining MRI and needle-OCT; 2) invented a novel fiber-based optical sensing technology named coherence-gated Doppler (CGD) for neurosurgical guidance; 3) demonstrated deep brain functional neuroimaging using needle-based voltage-sensitive dye imaging and fluorescence laminar optical tomography; 4) developed needle-based OCT imaging for spinal tissues; 5) investigated polarization-sensitive OCT (PS-OCT) for neural and spinal tissues; and 6) investigated X-rays-induced brain stimulation via optogenetics using novel photoluminescence nanoparticles.

Intellectual Merits: This program integrates research and education in biophotonics imaging, medical imaging, and neuroscience. This work provides a better understanding of neuro-networks, and results in several novel imaging platforms, including a parallel optical imaging platform for investigation of thalamocortical feedback loop and sensori-motor cortex connectivity, as well as multi-scale imaging of neural structure and function.

Broader Impact: The research activities have been seamlessly integrated with educational, mentoring, and outreach activities to advance the multi-disciplinary program in the field of Photonic Neural Imaging at the University of Maryland (UMD). It strengthens the research and educational connections between the UMD School of Engineering in College Park and the UMD School of Medicine in Baltimore. We integrate research into both undergraduate and graduate courses emphasizing hands-on teaching methods to improve student learning outcomes. In addition, we have organized an art exhibition at the American Center for Physics (ACP) based on biomedical imaging including optical/MRI images of brain. The exhibition, entitled "From Here to Infinity", was held from October 2012 - April 2013. The estimated attendance of the exhibition is around 1,500-2,000. Furthermore, the PI has co-edited a textbook on “Advanced Neurophotonics and Brain Mapping”.
